question.title: How likely is it I will be prosecuted?
question.body: I am roughly $30k in credit card debt. About a year ago I had left my job and applied for two credit cards and stated on the application I was employed. I have several other cards that have defaulted but those applications were accurate, the ouch they were close to maxed at the time. I had money from my retirement that I was using to pay my bills and pay more than the minimum balance believing I would soon be employed with similar income. I finally got a job a few months later, but with a significant pay cut. After a couple of months I realized I wasn’t going to be able to keep up with everything (cards maxed out at this point) so I enrolled in a debt relief program (changed midstream to another company). This has ruined my credit and now I am considering filing for bankruptcy. I haven’t paid my credit cards in 6 months. How likely is it that they will discover I wasn’t truthful on my applications during the bankruptcy process, and if so, how likely is it that I will be prosecuted and go to jail? I know I’ve made a lot of stupid mistakes, but honestly thought I could handle the debt. I think bankruptcy is the best option if the risk is low, otherwise I may have to continue this way

0.answer_text: I agree that it is unlikely the credit card company who seek to have you prosecuted. It is possible they could seek to have the debts on those cards declared nondischargeable in your bankruptcy, but that is also unlikely unless you've made a lot of charges in the 90 days prior to the filing of your bankruptcy.

1.answer_text: I understand your concern but I do not think this will come up as an issue. Credit card companies almost never challenge a bankruptcy and when they do it relates to charges within 90 days of the bankruptcy. Seriously.

2.answer_text: My best guess is that the credit card company won't even look at your credit application, much less find out that you were unemployed at that time. Also, I've never heard of submitting an erroneous credit card application being prosecuted as a crime.

question.title: Bankruptcy and Keeping Home?
question.body:
My fiance and I bought a home with an FHA loan and the deed is Tenancy in Common. We have yet to be married, and we are thinking about filing chapter 7 bankruptcy . We would like to keep the home, just drop off some debt that she has accumulated.
She went to see a lawyer and he said she should not reaffirm the home loan. I’m wondering what will be the ramifications. He said we will be able to stay in the home, continue to make payments, they will not be able to foreclose, and her name will drop off the loan. He just told us we need to continue making payments as usual.
Does this sound right? I can’t imagine a bank going through all the trouble of making sure a couple has enough money to afford a home just to not care that one person is getting off the loan. If this is the case, will it affect our ability to refinance the loan in the future?
Just looking for reassurance here. Appreciate any help.

0.answer_text:
The attorney with whom you consulted may not have conveyed the information in a manner that garnered your trust, but fundamentally he or she is correct.

The lender did not extend the loan primarily based upon borrower income, but rather upon the value of the collateral, i.e., the home. For that reason, the lender will happily continue to receive and apply payments to the loan in accordance with its terms, as its lien created by the deed of trust will "ride through" the bankruptcy without becoming impaired.

Homesteads have no significance in this situation, since the homestead does not take priority over the consensual lien given to secure the loan. Homesteads are effective against involuntary liens, such as judgment liens.

In addition, even in the context of a bankruptcy proceeding I have never seen a bankruptcy judge approve a reaffirmation agreement for residential real property in my 44 years of practice. While the judge's approval is not required in the event that the debtor's attorney certifies that entering into the reaffirmation agreement will not result in a hardship to the borrower, there really is no need to reaffirm the loan, except for credit reporting purposes.

1.answer_text:
1. Make sure she meets with a CA State Bar Certified Bankruptcy Specialist. Make sure the attorney has filed at least 1,000 cases. Make sure they are a member of the National Association of Consumer Bankruptcy Attorneys. These 3 things can help ensure she gets competent advice from an experienced attorney. And, don't be afraid to ask about these things. You have every right to research the attorney you are hiring. I also recommend meeting with 3 attorneys before making your decision. You need to make sure they are also the right fit for you.

2. The homestead exemption in Los Angeles County for 2023 was appx. $678,000 in equity, but the numbers for 2024 are not available until around the 20th of January each year. Given last year's poor real estate market, this number could actually go down. However, other factors, such as when you purchased the home may limit that homestead exemption amount also - this is often missed by attorneys who are inexperienced or who dabble in bankruptcy and who do not stay current on the changes in the law. I've had to take over numerous cases where the attorneys missed this issue and the trustee was going to force the sale of the home because of that error.

4. We never reaffirm homes in California. California has an anti-deficiency statute. You keep making your payments and they cannot show your home loan as defaulted due to the bankruptcy. They may quit reporting it on your credit, but there's nothing anyone can do about that because they are not required to report anything. Reaffirmation agreements help the lenders not the borrowers.

5. Not sure what you mean by "getting off the loan." Bankruptcy does not remove anyone from the loan. It just discharges personal liability. The bank will still have its lien on the home and that will always needs to be paid or it can foreclose.

Happy to help.

2.answer_text:
Depending on the amount of equity and how recently you purchased, the homestead exemption is likely limited ... this doesn't sound like a good idea.

There isn't any such thing as a name "dropping off of a loan."

Reaffirmation isn't really an issue for a purchase money loan on residential real estate, because the lender is required to exhaust security (selling the house) before going after the borrower personally, and the lender is unable to obtain a deficiency on a purchase money loan, if the sale price is not enough to cover the balance owed.

question.title: Chapter 7 bankruptcy/The only asset I own is a paid off 2022 Dodge ram that I use to travel to and from work? ?
question.body: I'm going to be filing for chapter 7 bankruptcy. I own a 2022 Dodge ram valued at $40,000 that's fully paid off. That's the only asset that I own. I use it to travel to and from work. Without my truck, I'd be unable to get to and from work and end up losing my job. The question is if I file chapter 7 bankruptcy, can my only vehicle be taken forcing me not to have a way to get to and from work?

0.answer_text: I agree with my colleagues; you may be able to protect the vehicle, but it depends. You need this analyzed by a qualified bankruptcy attorney. You should not be trying to do a bankruptcy on your own. The forms are the final product to the legal work and if you get the legal work wrong, you risk losing assets.

1.answer_text: Yeah, I hear the excuse of "the only asset I own is...." so often that I know you aren't aware that your clothes, pension, retirement or 401K, unpaid wages, your iPhone, etc., must all be listed in your bankruptcy. If you continue with this attitude and file for bankruptcy, you might face serious blowback. In bankruptcy, everything you own must be disclosed as an asset. While exempting your vehicle if you don't have other significant assets is possible, claiming that you "need" a $40K vehicle to get to work is rather pretentious. Many people have vehicle loans or drive less expensive vehicles and also have to get to work. If you file a Chapter 7 bankruptcy, you might need to decide if you have confused your wants with your expectations of what you "need." Doing this is a sure way to get you back in financial trouble. Hope this perspective helps!

2.answer_text: The California wildcard set of exemptions could be used to protect the equity in your vehicle. I would strongly suggest you discuss your assets and other information with experienced bankruptcy counsel to make sure there are no other issues with either your assets or debts.

3.answer_text: The bankruptcy laws allow people to keep assets considered necessities of life, the legal buzzword is exemptions. In California, the law allows you to retain clothes, furniture, pension, 401(k) and a host of other assets. When it comes to a vehicle, the law allows you to keep a vehicle worth up to $7,500 but also has a "wildcard" exemption that allows you to retain $33,650 worth of assets not otherwise protected. You valued the truck at $40k, and that means you can keep it if you file chapter 7.

question.title: I'm forced to file bk 7 will I be able to stop paying rent for 6 months ?
question.body: Enforced to file chapter 7 to wipe out tax debt with the IRS and the franchise tax board in California. I'm broke my business failed, and I have no income other than my $2700 a month of Social Security/disability. The problem is the rent is 2550 I understand is it true I can stop paying rent for six months Putting the landlord with the bankruptcy?

0.answer_text: Although my distinguished colleagues have provided you with excellent advice about the rent issue, they did not address the tax issues. I am not a CA tax attorney, but I suspect that the taxes are not going to be dischargeable. You need to contact both an experienced CA tax attorney about the dischargablity of the taxes. Good luck. THIS IS NOT LEGAL ADVICE! YOU NEED TO SPEAK TO AN ATTORNEY WHO IS LICENSED IN YOUR STATE FOR LEGAL ADVICE. This is merely suggestions for you to think about in discussing your situation with the local attorney.

1.answer_text:
Any rent due and unpaid prior to filing would likely be dischargeable, but you would still owe any unpaid rent for the period you occupied the property after filing.
The bankruptcy code also allows landlords to expedite their motions for relief from stay where you are not paying and have made no provision to pay that rent.
I would recommend that you obtain less expensive housing before filing, and you can discharge any remainder due under your current lease, and still have a home. It is very difficult to find new housing immediately after filing.

2.answer_text:
No. If you stop paying rent, your landlord will file a motion for relief from the stay in order to proceed with evicting you
That motion will be granted and you will be evicted. You would not have to pay for any unpaid rent that you owed at the time you filed, but any rent that comes due after filing and during which you occupy the premises, you will be responsible for. If you file, you could vacate the unit without paying the remainder of the rent due under the lease, but bk does not give you a free place to live.

question.title: I have a SBA EIDL loan and my business has closed 2 years ago. ?
question.body: I was in an accident and have a $40k SBA EIDL loan, I have been living on credit cards for a few months now? My business has been closed for over 2 years and there are no assets avail. Is there a way to get out from under this loan without default or bankruptcy?

The only way to avoid default is to pay/pay off the loan. There is no pre-default option to forgive the loan. Until you default, you are not a loss risk. question.title: Can I file Bankruptcy to get rid of my student loans in CA?
question.body: Hi, I have over $100,000 student loan debt but because I graduated in Dec 2019, I never made the payments due to Covid. Now that the payments started again, with the interest rate and all, I am not in a condition to make the payments. I do not make enough and also going through a divorce. Is there any possibility of getting rid of my loans through bankruptcy? I have some credit card and medical debt too, which I don't even know how to starting paying all of it. With a divorce process and now living in LA on single income, when I have to take care of my day to day expenses, I am in no position to make these payments. I make $60,000 a year.

0.answer_text:
It is possible to discharge student loans, but only after a trial with the Bankruptcy Judge (there is no jury in bankruptcy court), and you have to prove basically that you are forced to choose between eating and paying your loans (the Brenner test), both for now and for the foreseeable future. It is a difficult hill to claim, but a doctor was able to cancel over $300K in student loans a couple of years ago.

GOOD LUCK

1.answer_text:
It is really too soon. If you only graduated in 2019, and unless there is something seriously wrong with you physically or mentally that prevents you from or limits your ability to work and earn income, you are a poor candidate for a bankruptcy discharge of student loans. If your situation doesn't improve much over the next 6 or more years, then you might be a slightly better candidate. However, it is virtually impossible for recent graduates to discharge student loans absent some sort of life-altering catastrophe. Beyond that, you haven't made a payment (granted, that is due to COVID-19 forbearances), but you cannot discharge student loans in bankruptcy unless you have "tried" to repay them for some time.

You need to get on the SAVE repayment program. You should be able to afford that payment. Call your servicer or go online and apply for SAVE repayment. That program is likely the one that will give you the lowest payment.

2.answer_text:
While it is technically possible to get student loans discharged, discharge is not automatic based on the borrower's current income alone. This jurisdiction follows the 3-part "Brunner test" which is:

1. The debtor cannot maintain, based on current income and expenses, a minimal standard of living for herself and her dependents if forced to repay the loans;
2. Additional circumstances exist indicating that this state of affairs is likely to persist for a significant portion of the repayment period of the student loans; and
3. The debtor has made good faith efforts to repay the loans.

It sounds like you would meet the first "prong" of the test, but maybe not the second and third. "Additional circumstances" may be found if the debtor is physically or mentally disabled, does not work due to child-care responsibilities, or has reached the maximum income for his or her occupation and that income is not enough to make payments on loans. People who are working full-time and in the early stages of a career are probably not good candidates for this type of discharge.

If you have federal student loans, apply for income-based repayment aka IBR or IDR, which will make the payment a percentage of your disposable income. You would have to re-certify every year, but after 20 or 25 years in an IBR program, your loans would be discharged.

3.answer_text:
You may have your federal student loan discharged in bankruptcy only if you file a separate action, known as an "adversary proceeding," requesting the bankruptcy court find that repayment would impose undue hardship on you and your dependents. The bankruptcy courts do not use a single test to determine undue hardship but may look at the following factors to determine whether requiring you to repay your loans would cause an undue hardship: If you’re forced to repay the loan, you would not be able to maintain a minimal standard of living; There is evidence that this hardship will continue for a significant portion of the loan repayment period; You made good faith efforts to repay the loan before filing bankruptcy.

While you may not be able to discharge student loan debt by filing for bankruptcy, credit card and medical debt is dischargeable.

question.title: Will my family member lose their car if i file bankruptcy, we are both on the car title?
question.body: My family member and I are both on the title of a car and i plan on filing ch7 but not sure if they will take the car away from her ? I was only a cosigner but when the car was paid off i was added to the title as a second owner of the car(back in 2020). 0.answer_text:
The previous attorney answers are all correct and valid. I would offer the following as another thought:

The Trustee does not want your car. S/He wants money to pay unsecured creditors. Sometimes, if a debtor has an asset (or "exposed" equity in an asset) the debtor can get a loan for the amount of that exposed equity.

In this case, there are 2 owners, and theoretically 2 people who could be considered liable on the loan (let's assume that you are both on the loan). If the car has $3K in exposed equity (assume a car worth $10K and an exemption of $7K), then it may be possible for you or your family member to secure a loan for $3K and pay that to the Trustee to "bail out" that asset.

I know that this is possible for exposed equity in a home, so it may be worth thinking about for your car.

GOOD LUCK

1.answer_text:
To accurately answer your question, the volunteer attorneys need to know 1) what this vehicle is worth, 2) whether you own any other vehicles, and if so, what these vehicles are worth, and 3) what the value of your other assets is.

Although you are looking for a free answer to an important question, you must appreciate that an answer doesn't just come from a Magic 8 ball. What will happen is based on specific financial details you have not, and probably should not, reveal in a public forum like Avvo. Hope this perspective helps!

2.answer_text: It is not likely the car would be taken away but it depends on your overall assets and what can and cannot be exempted. You will benefit from consulting with a bankruptcy attorney in your area that can go into detail about your specific situation.

3.answer_text: The car is probably exempt by using a wild card provision in California's exemption statutes but to definitively decide on which of the two exemption schemes California law allows you should use, you should have a couple of consultations with experienced local bankruptcy attorneys who can advise you of how to best protect the car and other assets you have and answer any other questions. Most bankruptcy attorneys offer free initial consultations so it won't cost you anything but time.

question.title: My brother filled a DE-120 can I fill one also?
question.body:
My father died on Nov. 18 2023 and his name is the only name on the deed.
My brother filled a DE-120 to petition for probate . there is no will. and my brothe states on petition that the house has market value of less than 390,000.00 for encumbrances.So the value is only 260,000.00
Can I fill a DE-120 or what can I do?

0.answer_text:
Yes, under California law, you have the option to file a DE-120 Petition for Probate as well, especially if you have concerns or different intentions regarding the probate process for your father's estate. Since your father passed away without a will (intestate), the court will oversee the distribution of his assets.

If your brother has already filed a DE-120, it's essential to coordinate with him or consult with an attorney to ensure both of your interests are appropriately addressed in the probate proceedings. The value of the estate, as mentioned in your brother's petition, may impact the probate process, so discussing the property's actual value and any encumbrances with your brother and an attorney is advisable.

question.title: If you file bankruptcy do you still pay on a judgement? I also have credit card debt and drowning.
question.body: When covid hit it hit me hard maxed out cc I live in a motel now I lease a car and the debt is getting worse. If I filed bankrupt does a judgement be included and do I get to keep my car for work?

0.answer_text:
Depends on what the judgment is for and whether the judgment is for a debt which is not dischargeable and whether that creditor files an action to keep that debt from being discharged

Typically, if the debt isn't from fraud or some willful/malicious act (or, in the 6th circuit, a grossly negligent act), and is just a judgment for non payment of an unsecured debt, it should be fine.

1.answer_text:
A court judgment is nothing more than a judicial determination that you owe the money. The judgment is just as dischargeable as the debt for which the lawsuit was filed in the first place. Unless you own real estate that could be made subject to a judgment lien, you should be able to discharge the judgment along with all of your other debts.

As far as the car, you will need to notify the lender of your bankruptcy, and the lender will continue to have a lien or otherwise known as a security interest in the car until you finish paying off the loan, but you can keep the car and continue to make the payments. You also have the option of "reaffirming" the car loan, i.e., agreeing to be bound by the loan terms, not just the lien. But you are not required to do so in California. Nevertheless, if you reaffirm the car loan, you will get positive credit reporting and the lender will generally reinstate your ability to make payments online or check the balance at any time.

I am sorry to hear of your difficulties and hope that you are able to pursue a bankruptcy to discharge the debts and start fresh with a clean slate.

However, I have no idea what you mean by "drowning." It would be more helpful to explain that your pay was being garnished or your bank account was attached. This sort of hyperbole is a pet peeve of mine; you don't need to be dramatic to get my attention. Hope this perspective helps!

question.title: Can a creditor foreclose on a debtor's Single Member LLC in CA after obtaining default judgment ? Or go after LLCs assets ?

Debt is Credit Card .

0.answer_text:
You ask an exceedingly general question.

Thus, we can only give a general answer.

Generally, If I get a judgment against an LLC, I can do what I could to a human to that LLC.

Thus, if the LLC owned realty, and I had a lien against the realty and state law allowed my foreclosure of that lien, sure, I could foreclose.

If the LLC has a bank account, I could levy it.

If the LLC is being used as an alter ego of a person an I file an appropriate action alleging this, I could pierce the corporate veil.

Piercing isn't common, per se. But if the allegations pre petition involve significant co mingling, and mismanagement, I'd say that's likely in the future (veil piercing, that is).

Foreclose is a term that applies to secured real estate transactions, such as mortgages. So, if the LLC has financed a real estate purchase, the lender can foreclose on the real estate. However, I am guessing you want to know whether an LLC can be ATTACHED by a judgment creditor of one of the owners of the LLC.

In Nevada, state exemption laws protect business entities such as LLCs, but I am unaware California offers such protection to its residents. Accordingly, a judgment creditor can probably rip the LLC to shreds with some effort. Hope this perspective helps!

question.title: Can a creditor foreclose on a debtor's Single Member LLC in CA after the default Judgment ?

Debt is Credit Card .

0.answer_text:
In California, a creditor generally cannot foreclose on a debtor's Single Member LLC to satisfy a debt, such as a credit card debt, after obtaining a default judgment. Single Member LLCs are considered separate legal entities, and California law typically protects the personal assets of the LLC owner from being used to satisfy the LLC's debts. However, there are exceptions and certain circumstances where creditors may attempt to pierce the corporate veil and go after the personal assets of the LLC owner, but this is not common and requires specific legal criteria to be met.

Creditors usually pursue other collection methods, like garnishing bank accounts or placing liens on other assets, rather than trying to foreclose on a Single Member LLC. Foreclosure on an LLC is a more complex and less common process compared to foreclosure on real property.

It's essential for debtors to consult with an attorney who can provide advice tailored to their specific situation, as the outcome can vary depending on various factors and legal nuances. Consulting a legal professional will help you understand the best course of action for your specific case.

1.answer_text:
In the situation you describe, where a creditor has a judgment for a consumer debt, the most common methods of collection are wage garnishments and bank levies. Funds in a bank account can be levied by the creditor if the account is in the name of the judgment debtor.

To access property owned by a business entity, the creditor would have to "pierce the corporate veil" by proving the the business entity is the "alter ego" of the judgment debtor. This requires a significant investment of time and effort, and is therefore unlikely in the typical consumer debt case. However if you are the sole owner of the LLC, and personal or business assets are at risk, consult with a bankruptcy attorney.
